subject: Re: [junit] question about Assert.assertEquals
msgSnippet: (I think only the second, whoops message got through, so I ve resent this one, apologies for the duplication) ... Okay, the equals method in the java.util.Set
messageBody:
(I think only the second, whoops message got through, so I've resent
this one, apologies for the duplication)

--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Consider the template code:
>
> public boolean equals(Object other) {
> if (other != null && getClass() == other.getClass()) {
> MyClass that = (MyClass) other;
> // compare fields or whatever you like
> }
> else {
> return false;
> }
> }
>
> I claim that this implementation of equals fully supports the
> contract of Object#equals, including the subclass/superclass case. If
> you think that is false, then please show us a test consistent with
> the contract of Object#equals that this implementation does not pass.

Okay, the equals method in the java.util.Set interface, and the two
implementations HashSet and TreeSet.

According to the Set interface definition of equals, two Sets are equal
if they have the same size, and all the contents of one are contained
in the other.

Your approach would return false in the case where you have two sets
full of the same object, but one is the HashSet implementation and the
other is the TreeSet implementations.

Granted, you said Object.equals (with transitivity, etc), but what
we've been talking about is equals implementations as relates to
subclasses. My point is, the instanceof approach also fufills the
Object.equals contract, without breaking *this* case.

This leads into a discussion of when you should allow subclass
equality, and when to deny it, which I'd find interesting, but is
probably too far offtopic for this list.

-Kevin
